captions.text:
Have you ever wondered how the earth stays
in orbit around the sun? I mean, the pull

of gravity is stronger the closer you are
to the sun, so you'd think that if the earth

got bumped slightly towards the sun (like,
if you jumped, or something), then the sun

would pull just a little bit stronger, tugging
the earth yet closer still, at which point

the sun's pull would be stronger yet again,
… and the earth would spiral in to its eventual
doom.

But you and I and swiss cheese are clearly
evidence that the earth doesn't just spiral

in to its doom – so why not? Well, when
the earth does get pushed a little bit towards

the sun, the sun's pull speeds it up a little
bit, too - so even though the nearby sun's

pull is stronger, the earth will be going
fast enough that it overshoots and ends up

farther away from the sun. Of course, the
sun's pull slows it down again in the process…

at which point the earth turns back and starts
the cycle all over again.

The amazing thing is that the two effects
of speeding up plus stronger gravitational

attraction perfectly balance, so that the
earth stays in its orbit the same way a marble

stays at the bottom of a bowl even if it gets
knocked around a little bit.

This balance is very special indeed - it's
highly dependent on the strength of the gravitational

force and the number of dimensions we live
in, and in fact, these stable orbits only
exist in a three dimensional universe.

The details are a bit subtle, but if gravity
were just slightly steeper, as it would be

if we lived in four spatial dimensions, you
could never orbit the sun because you'd get

pulled in without picking up enough speed
to escape and you WOULD spiral in to your

doom. And if we lived in fewer dimensions
so that gravity were a bit tamer, then you

could ALSO never orbit the sun, because as
you approached it, you wouldn't be pulled

enough and would merely pass by with your
path slightly bent.

So we're incredibly lucky to live in a three
dimensional universe where there ARE stable

orbits that allow planets, solar systems,
and galaxies to exist at all! Thank you, stable

orbits, for without you, life as we know it,
and especially cheese, would be impossible.

ps An awesome down-to-earth example of stable
orbits are the hyperbolic funnels that you

often see at museums or in shopping malls:
the physics is almost identical to the stable

orbits of planets, satellites, and moons,
and the only reason the coins in the funnels

(or satellites around the earth) eventually
DO spiral in to their doom is because they

lose energy to friction and thus shift down
from one stable orbit to another, until eventually,

their orbit coincides with the ground. Which
is called crashing.

title: Why the solar system can exist

It's not really perfect. And, if it were in a way that we couldn't exist we 
wouldn't exist to note that fact. The universe isn't made for us. We simply 
happen to fill in the hole, like water in a cup. And the universe isn't 
random. It interacts in very specific ways, some of which are well 
understood and some that are still puzzling. Except for quantum mechanics. 
The wave like nature of gauge bosons makes them probabilistic until we 
actually interact with them. It's not like dropping sticks and making 
words. It's like dropping iron fillings around a magnet and getting a 
magnetic field drawn out in the filings.

comments.text:
4D math is extremely complicated. We would no longer orbit in a circle with 
eccentricity, but rather a sphere. But not like tracing the circle until it 
covers every possible space, but covers the surface area all in one orbit, 
which of course is extremely hard for our 3D thinking minds to visualize. 
In fact, we would see a circle, which is what I meant by "a fairly circular 
orbit" above. We can't see the sphere.

I'm pretty sure this would be impossible to explain sensibly...

comments.author: nerfzinet

comments.text:
the way gravity weakens with distance is similar to spraying water from a 
hose. in three dimensions, if you spray water in a cone, the water spreads 
out to form the base of the cone. as you go out, the base's area increases 
with the square of the distance from the origin. likewise, in 2 dimensions, 
the water would spray in a triangle, and the base widens with the distance 
from the origin by itself. in 4 dimensions, the water sprays in the 4d 
equivalent of a cone, and the "base" would be a sphere whose volume 
increases with the cube of the distance of the origin.

comments.author: Vincent Miller

comments.text:
+Bartek Struszczyk The force of gravity is famously explained by newton to 
be F = G*((m1)*(m2)/r^2)     - and yes that does look abit wierd without 
subscript and superscript. Anyways, the famous way to get infinity in a 
division is by dividing with 0, meaning r^2 would equal zero meaning r = 0, 
which means that infact, you are not traveling towards the black hole, but 
because your distance to the black hole is 0, you ARE the black hole. To be 
more precise, speaking quantum'ly, the minimum aquirable distance is a 
plank length, which means that even being the black hole creates some 
obsenely large number instead of infinity.

I guess the other way would be having m1 or m2 be infinite but then you 
would get the problems of dividing infinity by a number(say 2) and then you 
have created yourself half an infinity which is still an infinity and you 
have both created a paradox and realised why infinity is in a 
mathematicians eye not an answer to any equation but instead a peasant's 
way to always want to give a number as an answer to a calculation rather 
than just using an expression.

And if that wasnt enough, having m1 or m2 be infinte becomes slightly 
worrying since that means either you or the black hole has infinite mass, 
breaking quite a few laws of nature.

The last way is having big G, the gravitational constant, be infinte. I 
really hope I dont have to explain to you why that is stupid.

Hello abdulmalek. What you described and what the video is about is the 
same thing. Nothing conflicting here. 
As for why doesn't earth fall on the sun, simply because it orbits. 
What is that? On your model with a cloth, and two balls you forgot to make 
earth roll around it. Ever seen the casino game : Roulette? With the little 
ball spinning multiple times around the roulette before touching it. 
Well it's the same in space, but as there is (barely) no friction slowing 
down earth it just spins way longer. With your cloth it might go around one 
or twice but the ball rolling on tge cloyh slows it down. That's why it's 
only a metaphor, an easy way to represent really hard physics.

comments.author: Yağız Ozan Dibek

comments.text:
+Yağız Ozan Dibek
Earths atmosphere theoretically ends at 300 miles or 483 kilometers but in 
reality while extremely thin it expands even higher than that. We are 
talking air ridiculously thin, but when traveling at 4.66 miles/second (7.5 
km/second) an extremely small amount of air can still have a noticeable 
impact.
Lets just guess *and I am probably way off one way or the other* that the 
air is 1/1,000 as thick as sea level. that would give it the same drag as 
if it were going about 17 miles per hour at sea level. For reference hubble 
is 43 feet long. That is a fair amount of drag. It takes time but it 
decays, they have had to boost its orbit. It has been around for a while 
and they have had to boost it a few times or it would have crashed by now.

http://images.spaceref.com/news/2003/07.31.03.hubble.3.jpg

Our sun emits solarwinds that extend well beyond the orbits of the planets, 
and even outside our solar system you have interstellar winds.
We are learning how to study the interaction between the interstellar wind 
and the heliosphere.

So there is virtually no friction in space, but when you travel fast enough 
for long enough it does not take much to noticeably change your path.

Thanks for explaining this! This question kept bugging me. Constantly 
thinking of trying to let a marble spiral around a hole without falling 
into it, made me think think we would be on such a thin line between orbit 
and doom.
This also talks about something I never heard about before. I thought a 
marble would not be able to spiral infinitly because of its energy loss as 
it rolls (or even the earths movement itself) but if I understand 
correctly, even if those 2 factors were not having any effect, it would 
still be impossible because the marble is moving over a 2D space? Very 
interesting stuff.﻿

comments.author: M Hanson

comments.text:
This was explained to me slightly different in school:
You are in an (circular) orbit if the centripetal force (or centrifugal 
force) of your circular motion around the sun cancels out the gravitational 
force. This also explains the microgravity in an orbit. This means that 
orbits still are possible even if the gravitational constant would change. 
If the Sun got heavier for example, so if the suns gravitational parameter 
got bigger, it would only lower the Periapse of Earths orbit.﻿

comments.text: so....does this refute string theory?﻿
comments.author: Anita Bonghit

comments.text:
+Anita Bonghit Sorry for replying to a old comment, but i hope you see this.
There is no mystery that we live in 3 spatial dimensions, we can see that 
both in the force of gravity or, say the dispersion of gas. Some have tried 
to still make string theory valid by explaining that there could be more 
dimensions "tucked away", and therefore not affect our everyday life, but 
still be there to allow for strings.
You might be thinking, that's just crazy. And the point is it might be, 
since there is no proof, although there isn't a disproof yet either.
comments.author: Jón Aron Lundberg

comments.text:
+sean cuff string theory refutes nothing because its an untested 
hypothesis. if the orbits prove we live in a 3d universe and not 4, not 5, 
not 6. then string theory must be wrong
comments.author: Anita Bonghit

comments.text:
Its complicated. but short story is gravity only affects 3 dimensions. dark 
matter may affect 3 dimensions but a different three. such as 4 - 7. since 
we cant perceive these, its hard to prove its there. we can see some form 
of evidence though since even the earth is heavier than first thought just 
based on mass. some underlying force is in effect making the earth heavier. 
and all the galaxy's and stars holding the universe together. since if you 
calculate all the mass of the universe it only equates to a THIRD of the 
needed gravity to make it as we perceive it to be (3D). without this force 
the universe would be 2D. so string theory doesn't refute this. its helps 
explain it. hope this helps. also this is my understanding. if I'm wrong 
then meh I'm not a scientist or anything; physics is just an interest.
comments.author: sean cuff

comments.text: +Gled ShadowBroker string theory only holds in 11 dimensions

comments.author: Oliver Morgan

comments.text:
+Fred Wells Kinetic energy from drag is transferred from the object to the 
air particles and/or is transferred into thermal energy.
+Shaun Bell The Earth doesn't encounter friction from the sun... As far as 
I know, there are a few particles in interplanetary space, but the Earth's 
mass is too great, and there are too few of them for it to really have an 
affect on it's orbit.
comments.author: MrSplodgeySplodge

comments.text:
+David Moutard
In space there is nothing to slow you down. So unless acted upon by a force 
you will keep moving. So the sun in this case is (the main) thing acting 
upon the earth so the only friction that it incounters is the sun itself. 
Which balances its self. The same thing with satellites, they have the 
earth as their main force. They don't really get affected by the sun 
because the earths pull is so huge. So the suns pull doesn't really matter. 
And same thing goes with the sun, The planets arnt pulling the sun toward 
them. Then as a bigger scale the sun is in orbit around the black hole at 
the center of the galaxy. Also like a magnet, smaller something is the 
slower it will attract to the magnet, but it has less friction so it will 
end up going faster. So a satellite will be dragged toward the sun slower 
then the earth but will end up going quicker. Or at least thats my 
understanding :P
comments.author: Shaun Bell

comments.text:
The satellites are encountering friction from the earths atmosphere (the 
exosphere to be exact). The atmosphere out here is thin, but it is there 
nonetheless. The satellites are running into friction where the earth does 
not. At least that's my guess, it makes sense to me.
comments.author: David Moutard
